answer_html: \(\lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=f(a)\) must be satisfied. Therefore, (i) is the answer.
answer_latex:
$\lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=f(a)$  must be satisfied. Therefore, (i)
is the answer.
hints_html: If a function is differentiable at a point \(x = a\), then it is ___________ at the point \(x = a\).
hints_latex:
If a function is differentiable at a point $x = a$, then it is
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ at the point $x = a$.
hints_raw: If a function is differentiable at a point <math>x = a</math>, then it is ___________ at the point <math>x = a</math>.
question: 1 (l)
sols_html:
The fact that \(f'(a)\) exists is equivalent to saying that the function \(f(x)\) is differentiable at \(x = a\).

Recall that a function must be continuous at a point to be differentiable at that point.

For the function to be continuous at a point \(x = a\), the condition

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x) = f(a)\end{aligned}\]

must be satisfied. Therefore, (i) is the answer.
sols_latex:
The fact that $f'(a)$ exists is equivalent to saying that the function
$f(x)$ is differentiable at $x = a$.

Recall that a function must be continuous at a point to be
differentiable at that point.

For the function to be continuous at a point $x = a$, the condition

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x) = f(a)
\end{align*} must be satisfied. Therefore, (i)
is the answer.
sols_raw:
The fact that <math>f'(a)</math> exists is equivalent to saying that the function <math>f(x)</math> is differentiable at <math>x = a</math>.

Recall that a function must be continuous at a point to be differentiable at that point. 

For the function to be continuous at a point <math>x = a</math>, the condition
:<math>
\lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x) = f(a)
</math>
must be satisfied. <span style=color:#0000FF>Therefore, (i) is the answer.</span>
statement_html:
If f’(a) exists, then \(\lim_{x\to{}a}f(x)\)

(i) equals f(a).

(ii) equals f’(a).

(iii) must exist, but may not equal f(a) or f’(a).

(iv) might not exist.

(v) None of the above.
statement_latex:
If f'(a) exists, then $\lim_{x\to{}a}f(x)$

(i) equals f(a).

(ii) equals f'(a).

(iii) must exist, but may not equal f(a) or f'(a).

(iv) might not exist.

(v) None of the above.
statement_raw:
If f'(a) exists, then <math>\lim_{x\to{}a}f(x)</math>

(i) equals f(a).

(ii) equals f'(a).

(iii) must exist, but may not equal f(a) or f'(a).

(iv) might not exist.

(v) None of the above.
